name: vampilehunter
text: A comment left by vampilehunter was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by thedice, riotnrrd, sgrabens)

name: robobogle
text: It's also funny that despite his "little kid-ness" he has better spelling, grammar, and punctuation than most of us posting on this site. Also, has anyone else ever tried writing on a typewriter and having it come out looking as good as this? It's tough. Phillipe is a tiny otter genius.

name: anonymous44
text: I've got a 1950 Olivetti Lettera 22, it still types all kinds of awesome if you hit the letters hard enough.

name: c_dizzle
text: Panel 4 definitely looks like he's hitting them hard enough. It's like the Franz Liszt of story-telling. He's totally into it.

name: gsail11
text: He's winking in panel 4, silly

name: bixschmix
text: He's little-kid winking, where they try to wink but because they don't quite understand how to do it, just end up blinking emphatically at you.

name: c_dizzle
text: Well it is a damn passionate wink. Derived of story-telling momentum AND a healthy dose of child ism, perhaps.

name: mangtastic
text:
Chubby for the Liszt reference.

That man could write one HELL of a piano piece.

name: tagrineth
text: "PUNCH the keys, for God's sake!"

name: broahsaurus
text: Year late chubby for a wonderful reference.

name: rawk5tar
text:
You're the man.

Now, dog.

name: stewieisgod13
text: That's awesome.

name: onepapertiger
text:
I'm rockin a Swiss-made HERMES 3000--which is apparently one of the finest "portables"--and it's STILL tricky as a motherfucker to get clean pages out of it.
As a MOTHERfucker.

name: scorpio_nadir
text: Especially with otter flippers.

name: pogo
text: I wonder if Philippe knows that "jewels" can have another meaning.

name: macseries
text: he doesn't really understand the meaning of the word "crave" though.  diction isn't one of his strong suits.

name: lolsworth
text: He DOESN'T EVEN HAVE FINGERS. Philippe kicks everyone on the Internet's ass SO HARD.

name: klaus
text: Cornelius is concerned.

name: zeroasalimit
text: He damn well should be. Philippe could outsell him due to the cute factor.

name: mrphaethon
text: Cornelius is not concerned, he is displaying a mildly patronizing paternal atmosphere as he enjoys watching his young friend's exploits.

name: hollis
text:
I think Cornelius is neither concerned nor patronizing. He is just bewildered at Philippe's multifaceted character. See the "bilingual palindromes" strip.

Also, I love the "Wink!" comment. Way to get into your own story, Philippe.

name: dropkickpikachu
text: He tries so hard to wink properly, too, like a little kid with not quite enough fine muscle control.

name: agika
text: I like how Phillipe winks with both eyes at once. That's how I winked when I was a kid, too.

name: dusty
text: One time as a kid, at an Italian restaurant I was practicing winking, after I managed to do it a couple times I noticed that some fat bald guy at another table was smiling and winking back at me. This remains one of the most horrifying experiences of my childhood.

name: zefiel
text: I always mimic the facial expression of people i'm drawing. Not good when you're sketching in the middle of a class. I am no longer five.

name: slalvation
text: I mimic the facial expressions of people I'm reading about!

name: tekende
text: I do this too sometimes. A book will say that someone nodded, or shook his/her head or whatever, and I'll do it too. I imagine it probably looks a little strange to outside observers.

name: deus
text:
This is true for many people, "the drow priestess pursed her lips", or for just people reading junk fantasy.
a chubby to balance.

name: spicyponyhead
text: Dammit, you're right. I just pursed my lips. ha!

name: dopamine
text: haha at least you don't add sound effects for your more dramatic poses. thats as good way to get people to stare at you, even in an art college. lol

name: mira
text: hoorah for the continuity of signature drink = water

name: zem
text: I don't remember that anywhere else. where's it from?

name: mira
text: right here , my good man!

name: zem
text: Oh yeah, hah. Cool.

name: scramblesthedog
text: Wow, that's commitment to continuity right there.

name: _cheesekayke
text: Whoa. That might be the most obscure reference-catch ever. You should probably use your memory for more noble pursuits... or not. I wouldn't.

name: epicurus
text: This strip is definitely in my top five. "Okay." said the police chief.

name: agika
text: Man, that's a heart-stopping conclusion right there. Both to the story and to your comment!

name: nutmeg
text: man you always quote my favorite line before i can, every gooddarn time. SCREW YOU EPICURUS! FUCK YOU!

name: nutmeg
text: and also.. a chubby.

name: epicurus
text:
Looks like you figured out the whole reason I even bothered to register an account - so I could put my mind-reading powers to good use by posting all your favourite lines.

Also, I see you know the name of the cream that the Venezuelan doctors use to get rid of me.

name: hollis
text: Chubby each for you and Nutmeg for the Lyle reference!  Awesome.

name: professoryes
text: More stories should end like that.

name: untilyouaresonude
text: "Yaaay! Done!"

name: ghostd
text: It ends on such a high note, too. The police chief acknowledges that Rip knew where the jewels were. So much literature leaves that to chance nowadays.

name: agika
text: So much could be learned from Phillipe.

name: agika
text: I like how Phillipe makes it work out so that Rip Berryrock didn't waste his money. He knows that real hard-boiled detectives never waste their money on plane tickets. Good job, Phillipe.

name: lux
text: The best part is he just rolls down his plane window and yells to the pilot. It's a nice little-kid touch.

name: prine
text:
Rip Berrycock gets on a plane to catch a criminal and is then dismayed to learn that the criminal has skipped town.

Last panel is beautiful.

name: prine
text: ...BerryROCK. Damn, now bizarro's going to tell me I'm subconsciously gay.

name: i_love_kate
text: You mean Retardo?

name: prine
text: Shit.

name: bizarro
text: Me am not thinking you are gay. Me am sure you are [/i]totally[i] straight.

name: fineoakstructure
text: damn...bizarro is so bizarro that he even bizarro'd his italics tags.

name: rasalghul
text: Doesn't Bizzaro say the opposite of what he means?  I think Bizzaro just called you out, prine.  He just did it 1 year before my comment.

name: _cheesekayke
text: ...A subconscious reference to Teodor's cranberry-dong?

name: catachresis
text:
Damn, this strip has such energy

RUN TO THE TYPEWRITER / TAP TAP TAP TAP TING TAP TAP TAP / OK DONE / RUN AWAY

name: wehavemagnums
text: Best to get a running start on a novel with so much mystery to it.

name: cicadalek
text: TAP TAP TAP *WINK* TAP TAP TING

name: paperboy_2000
text: Like Ray's sex life in the previous strip, sometimes you just have to run at a typewriter and hope it winds up as a hard-boiled detective novel.

name: boredom_man
text: If Mickey Spillane, you can just run to a typewriter, type about a hard-boiled detective running at a naked woman, and be assured that the shit will sell.

name: giantants
text: I worte and illustrated a very similar story in the third grade, but the main character was a cyborg with like a gun hand that also shot a grappling hook.

name: tekende
text: Wasn't that a Nintendo game? Bio-Commando or something like that?

name: bjorntd
text: And Metroid. But I'm not sure that Samus is a cyborg.

name: charchar
text: She's not. It's a cybernetic power suit

name: firesign
text: Well, Samus Aran got a grappling hook in Super Metroid, but Bionic Commando came out long before that, and featured the hook far more prominently.

name: tbtabby
text: BIONIC Commando, actually. There's a remake of the game coming to XBox Live, as well as a fully 3D sequel for the 360 and PS3.

name: fattypneumonia
text: Y'all some nerds .

name: charkie
text: This is exactly how I handle term papers in every way. "Yaaay! Done!"

name: cheeks_jd
text:
The CASE of the MYSTERY.

This reminds of me of my high school friend who used to put "CASE CLOSED" at the end of essays to confuse teachers.

name: whalethief
text: I love this strip. This has to be one of the best yet.

name: cousinted
text: His pacing might be shabby, but that writing is pretty solid for a five-year-old.

name: joeyramoney
text: phillipes' expression in panel four warrants a five.

name: bovine
text: notice how he doesn't know the word 'stewardess.' SO CUTE

name: mygoodfriend
text: He's also shaky on the meaning of crave.

name: thegrapist
text:
First strip
And it got me hooked.

name: geozimmdrake
text: my favorite part is when philippe says 'wink' and shuts both his eyes really tight

name: serf
text: the driving leg is the worst leg to be shot in

name: baryonyx
text: Especially whilst driving.

name: tekende
text: 'Cause then you're all like "oh man no I have been shot and I cannot drive now"

name: nokococo
text: Oh my god he is the cutest thing ever.  And who among us hasn't enjoyed a typewriter in such a hearty fashion?

name: autobahnbismark
text: My favorite part of the strip is how Phillipe CHARGES at the typewriter, and then runs away to do something else as soon as it is done. I wish I had that kind of zest for life.

name: tbtabby
text: Move over, Danielle Steel!

name: dapooka
text: Come to think of it (and speaking as a library professional) Phillipe writes better than Danielle Steel.

name: spinynorman
text:
I really don't like Anthony Lane much. He's too snarky. All of his reviews, while well-written and clever, are also very self-involved. I read reviews to find new aspects, flaws, and high points of either books or films, not to have some smart ass riff on and on for his own damn amusement.

On the other hand, this strip is fantabulous.

name: fineoakstructure
text:
I cede these points, but I still like Anthony Lane in general. He's mostly snarky when he really doesn't like a movie; his reviews of films he enjoys can be almost inspiring at times.

The self-involved nature is a requirement for New Yorker film critics, of course.

name: spinynorman
text: I'll give you that. The most irritating part is that when he does get self-indulgent and somewhat snarky it's hard to sift through it and figure out what's good or bad about the movie. The only thing he tells you are there to be set up for jokes, which you can't judge much off of.

name: fineoakstructure
text:
I agree, his snarky reviews are sometimes enjoyable and witty, or at least parts of them are; but I've noticed that often they're not even that clever; some of his supposed scathing barbs are pretty forced or just confusing at times.

For dismissive reviews, I'd much rather read most of the Onion AV Club reviewers, as they manage to deflate any bad movie with genuine wit while still not succumbing to the overwrought pomposity that Lane can delve into at times. They also remember to review the movie at some point, too.

name: spinynorman
text: Yeah. The AVClub has been one of my first hits whenever checking out movies. Their backlogs of movies (My Year of Flops, My Year of Cinema) are also pretty fascinating to read.

name: pogo
text: I have no idea who Anthony Lane is, and do not care to know.  That is my review of him.  Yay, done!

name: soticoto
text:
Nothing quite like Philippe's "wink" turning into a blink.
When I think back to it, when I was 5 I couldn't wink either, and no matter how hard I tried it always became a blink.

name: bungdeetle
text: Oh god... my stories were pretty much like this.

name: meowmix
text:
aawwwwwww that was so adorable.
I know its been said before, but Onstad really knows how to write kids.

name: catbark
text: I like to think Cornelius is saddened because he hasn't felt passion for writing such as Philippe's since "So Many Whales". But he's probably just anxious to get his typewriter back.

name: mulisha7
text: I love how, in all the Phillipe writing strips, he really has no idea where his story is going. He actually gets worried for his characters. That is why he is a special boy.

name: charchar
text: Rip Berryrock is in an airplane with rolled-down windows. I will not make a joke about shooting the breeze

name: nothingman
text: Special appearance by Cornelius!

name: ctaronno
text: I couldn't properly punctuate dialogue until 9th grade, Phillipe's doing alright.

name: lemminadetate
text: gotta love the two-eyed wink.

name: leon
text: Jesus Christ, Philippe is such an efficient writer. That couldn't have taken longer than five minutes. He probably could write the equivalent of the entire Hardy Boys anthology before bedtime.

name: ketelcat
text: Aaw will you look at him winking with both eyes =)

name: dj_douche
text: Philippe is awesome. That is all.

name: aamzed
text: Rip Berryrock would make a great porno name.

name: filetmignon
text: Oh how I love Philippe!

name: tonyhighwind
text: Man, I don't care what anybody says, that's a great job for a five-year old.  That kid's got chops.

name: fattypneumonia
text:
I hears "Rip Berryrock," I thinks Flintstones.

Also see: Ann Margrock, Cary Granite, Rock Quarry, Stony Curtis. And southern roots rockers Dash RipRock.

name: greenkoolayd
text: rip berryrock is a rather tough-sounding name.

name: iamthelolrus
text: I love Phillipe.  Also, he blinks with both eyes- for some reason I find that hilarious.

name: subactuality
text: This is my favourite Phillipe strip. It captures the thought process of a little kid making up a story as he goes along just perfectly .
